awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Impact of Public Participation in Constitution Making
awd_abstract_narration:
Direct public participation in the constitution-­drafting process has become more and more common since the 1980s, and is now a standard element of such processes around the world. Yet, we remain ignorant of the actual impact of these opportunities for participation.  The central question in this project is when, and how much, impact public participation through popular consultations and written submissions has on the final text of the constitution. 

This project will utilize cutting-­edge text analysis techniques to classify, model, and analyze the proposals that citizens of Brazil and South Africa sent to their constituent assemblies as well as the constitutional text these assemblies produced. Beyond the direct impact on the words of the constitutional text, this research project will also consider the more indirect ways in which public comments and petitions may have influenced the content of the constitution through agenda setting in the constituent assemblies. This quantitative analysis of the textual data will be supplemented with interviews with members of the constituent assemblies and the support staff that facilitated their work, and where possible, with the members of the public who participated. Insights gained from the quantitative text analysis will be compared with the accounts given by those involved in the process, in the end producing a complete account of the role that public participation played in the creation of these constitutions.

por.por_cntn:
With the funds from this NSF Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant, the Co-PI, Alexander Hudson, was able to complete field research for his dissertation entitled “The Impact of Public Participation in Constitution Making.” This field research consisted primarily of interviewing individuals who had an active role in drafting the constitutions of Brazil and South Africa, either as elected officials, activists, or legal advisors. The Co-PI also collected images of documents, and electronic files, which were created during these drafting processes. Of primary interest for this research was the collection of written submissions sent by citizens of these countries to their constitution drafting assemblies.

Mr. Hudson spent the better part of five months in Brazil. During this time he interviewed individuals who had participated in the constitution-drafting process. He also made contacts with many Brazilian scholars who have previously completed research on the constitution-making process there. Mr. Hudson also acquired digital transcriptions of the hand-written submissions from the public, and created a single tab-separated-values file containing over 72,000 of these written submissions from the Brazilian public, along with demographic information about the individuals who wrote them. These data will be invaluable in determining the impact of public participation on the constitution.

Following this research in Brazil, Mr. Hudson travelled to South Africa for a stay of approximately four months. During this time he interviewed individuals who had participated in the constitution-making process, took photographs of documents in the national archives, and collected electronic files. In South Africa, Mr. Hudson was able to interview some of the leading negotiators in the political process that ended Apartheid and led to South Africa’s democratic elections and constitution-making process.  He also interviewed a number of the leading constitutional law scholars in South Africa. At the South African national archive, Mr. Hudson photographed internal publications from the constitution-making process and the multi-party negotiations that took place earlier.

The documents and interviews collected during this field research will be vital for Mr. Hudson’s doctoral dissertation, which should be completed by late 2017.  This dissertation will make an important contribution to how scholars understand the impacts of public participation, and to the design of constitution-making processes around the world. Products from this research will be made available to both scholars and practitioners.

With suitable protections for the identities of interview respondents and other persons, much of the data collected during this research will be made available online after publication of the findings of this project. 

Beyond the immediate application to constitution-making processes, this research will be applied to other areas where policy makers engage with members of the public. Opportunities for citizens to comment on legislation, participate in budgeting decisions, and make other direct inputs on the policy process are increasing across many jurisdictions. The findings of this project will help us to understand what kinds of impacts we can expect from these activities, and provide guidance for developing these processes.

 


Last Modified: 10/02/2016
Modified by: Alexander E Hudson
